questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for an annual physical examination. He reports that his vision has progressively improved over the past 6 months and he no longer needs the glasses he used while driving. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include glyburide, hydrochlorothiazide, and enalapril. Examination shows 20/20 vision bilaterally. Fundoscopy shows a few microaneurysms of retinal vessels. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's improved vision?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased susceptibility to glare can be seen in darker colored eyes compared to lighter colored ones. However, it is an unlikely pathology. Increased susceptibility to glare is a finding of normal aging, most likely due to the effects of intraocular light scatter. It is increased in patients with cataract and would not present with an improvement in myopia in middle age.

B) CORRECT:

Denaturation of lens proteins leads to the loss of lens elasticity seen in presbyopia, a classic condition associated with aging. This patient is experiencing the phenomenon of “second sight,” in which presbyopia corrects a long-standing case of myopia, resulting in improved visual acuity due to lens changes.

C) INCORRECT:

Liquefication of the vitreous humor is a physiological aging process that leads to condensing and shrinking of the gel-like substance. The vitreous membrane can eventually detach from the retina (posterior vitreous detachment). However, this would cause a worsening in the patient's vision (e.g., floaters, photopsia, scotoma), not an improvement.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased ciliary muscle tone is a mechanism that causes decreased diameter of the ciliary muscle, leading to constriction and accommodation of the pupil. It also induces opening of the trabecular meshwork and drainage of aqueous humor. It would be a mechanism for decreasing intraocular pressure in an ocular emergency like glaucoma, but it would not improve myopia during middle age. Furthermore, ciliary muscle tone tends to decrease with aging.

E) INCORRECT:

Macular degeneration is classified into two major forms: dry and wet macular degeneration. Dry macular degeneration is caused by the deposition of drusen under the retinal pigment epithelium, and wet macular degeneration is associated with neovascularization in the subretinal space. Both conditions cause decreased visual acuity, scotomas, and eventually blindness. However, since these conditions lead to progressively worsening central visual impairment in old age, they would not present with increasing visual acuity in middle age, as seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's improvement in vision is likely due to presbyopia.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because he has been falling behind in school and his teachers have voiced concerns. The boy says that he has trouble reading the board but does not have trouble reading books or using a computer screen. He has no personal or family history of serious illness. Both his parents and his older sister wear eyeglasses. He takes no medications and his immunizations are up-to-date. Visual acuity is 20/40 in both eyes. Prescribing which of the following lenses is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Convex lenses help to focus light on the retina in patients with hyperopia. A patient with hyperopia is able to see objects at a far distance without difficulty but has trouble seeing objects at a near distance (e.g., books, computer screens, cell phone screens). This patient, however, has difficulty with long-distance vision (e.g., reading the board), which indicates myopia rather than hyperopia.

B) INCORRECT:

Progressive lenses are used in the treatment of presbyopia. Patients with this condition have difficulty focusing on objects viewed at arm's length or closer, which is not the case with this patient. Moreover, presbyopia almost exclusively affects adults.

C) INCORRECT:

Cylindrical lenses are prescribed for patients with astigmatism. Patients with this condition have a reduction in both near and far vision. Difficulty with vision only at a far distance is consistent with myopia, for which cylindrical lenses are not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Prismatic lenses are used in paralytic strabismus. While patients with paralytic strabismus can have deficient visual acuity, they typically also present with a compensatory head posture, diplopia, and/or impaired extraocular muscle function, none of which are seen here. Moreover, paralytic strabismus usually has a secondary cause (e.g., neuropathy, myopathy, demyelinating diseases, trauma).

E) CORRECT:

Concave lenses are used to correct myopia. The increased axial length of the eye in myopia results in the focal point of an image being anterior to the retina, leading to blurry far vision and clear near vision. Concave lenses diverge incoming light, allowing it to be focused on the retina. Although mild myopia does not always require correction, this patient's myopia with 20/40 vision has affected his daily activities (school performance) and, therefore, needs treatment. Asymptomatic children with severe myopia should also use corrective lenses in order to prevent bilateral refractive amblyopia.
Image Description:

Deviations in eye anatomy that affect refractory media (e.g., axial length of the eye, cornea curvature) can result in refractive errors.

Emmetropia: The axial length of the eye and refractive power are balanced, resulting in a focal point on the retina.

Myopia: An increased axial length of the eye or increased refractive power results in a focal point anterior to the retina. Near objects can be seen clearly but distant objects are blurred. This can be corrected using a concave (diverging) lens.

Hyperopia: A decreased axial length of the eye or decreased refractive power results in a focal point posterior to the retina. Distant objects and even near objects may be seen clearly depending on the ability of the lens to accommodate (generally, the younger the individual, the greater the ability to accommodate) and the degree of hyperopia. Hyperopia can be corrected using a convex (converging) lens.
questions.hint: Clear near vision with blurred far vision is consistent with myopia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the office for an annual physical examination. He reports that his vision has progressively improved over the past 6 months and he no longer needs the glasses he used while driving. Examination shows 20/20 vision bilaterally. Fundoscopy shows a few microaneurysms of retinal vessels. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's improved vision?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to your clinic by his mother because he has been falling behind in school, and his teachers have expressed concerns. He reports difficulty reading the board but has no trouble reading books or using a computer screen. He has no personal or family history of serious illness. Both parents and his older sister wear eyeglasses. He takes no medications and his immunizations are up to date. Visual acuity is 6/12 in both eyes. Which one of the following lenses is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Convex lenses help to focus light on the retina in patients with hyperopia. A patient with hyperopia is able to see objects at a far distance without difficulty but has trouble seeing objects at a near distance (e.g., books, computer screens, cell phone screens). This patient, however, has difficulty with long-distance vision (e.g., reading the board), which indicates myopia rather than hyperopia.

B) CORRECT:

Concave lenses are used to correct myopia. The increased axial length of the eye in myopia results in the focal point of an image being anterior to the retina, leading to blurry far vision and clear near vision. Concave lenses diverge incoming light, allowing it to be focused on the retina. Although mild myopia does not always require correction, this patient's myopia with 20/40 vision has affected his daily activities (school performance) and, therefore, needs treatment. Asymptomatic children with severe myopia should also use corrective lenses in order to prevent bilateral refractive amblyopia.

Key learning point: Myopia (nearsightedness) is corrected with concave (diverging) lenses, which move the focal point of distant objects back onto the retina to improve distance vision.
Image Description:

Deviations in eye anatomy that affect refractory media (e.g., axial length of the eye, cornea curvature) can result in refractive errors.

Emmetropia: The axial length of the eye and refractive power are balanced, resulting in a focal point on the retina.

Myopia: An increased axial length of the eye or increased refractive power results in a focal point anterior to the retina. Near objects can be seen clearly but distant objects are blurred. This can be corrected using a concave (diverging) lens.

Hyperopia: A decreased axial length of the eye or decreased refractive power results in a focal point posterior to the retina. Distant objects and even near objects may be seen clearly depending on the ability of the lens to accommodate (generally, the younger the individual, the greater the ability to accommodate) and the degree of hyperopia. Hyperopia can be corrected using a convex (converging) lens.

C) INCORRECT:

Cylindrical lenses are prescribed for patients with astigmatism. Patients with this condition have a reduction in both near and far vision. Difficulty with vision only at a far distance is consistent with myopia, for which cylindrical lenses are not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Prismatic lenses are used in paralytic strabismus. While patients with paralytic strabismus can have deficient visual acuity, they typically also present with a compensatory head posture, diplopia, and/or impaired extraocular muscle function, none of which are seen here. Moreover, paralytic strabismus usually has a secondary cause (e.g., neuropathy, myopathy, demyelinating diseases, trauma).

E) INCORRECT:

Progressive lenses are used in the treatment of presbyopia. Patients with this condition have difficulty focusing on objects viewed at arm's length or closer, which is not the case with this patient. Moreover, presbyopia almost exclusively affects adults.
questions.hint: Clear near vision with blurred far vision is consistent with myopia.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the ophthalmologist because of vision changes over the past several months. She has worn glasses for nearsightedness since adolescence and typically requires them for driving and distance vision. Recently, she has noticed that she does not need her glasses to read the newspaper or do close-up needlework. She reports no eye pain, redness, discharge, or floaters. Medical history is significant for hypertension treated with lisinopril. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Family history is unremarkable. She appears well. Visual acuity with her current distance correction is 20/20 in both eyes. Without correction, distance vision is 20/400 bilaterally. Near vision without correction is 20/25 in both eyes. Slit lamp examination shows no abnormalities. Intraocular pressure is 16 mm Hg in both eyes. Funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's improved near vision?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Presbyopia is the age-related loss of accommodation caused by decreased elasticity of the lens and typically begins in a patient's mid-40s. This condition can cause second sight, a temporary improvement in near vision without correction in previously myopic patients. Second sight occurs because the focal point of the lens shifts, partially compensating for its inability to accommodate. Visual acuity with distance correction remains normal.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypertensive retinopathy typically leads to gradual vision loss or visual field defects, not improved vision. In addition, funduscopic examination in this condition shows retinal vascular changes (e.g., arteriolar narrowing, cotton wool spots, hemorrhage).

C) INCORRECT:

Age-related macular degeneration leads to progressive central vision loss, not improved vision. In addition, funduscopic examination in this condition shows pigmentary changes and/or drusen.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute angle-closure glaucoma manifests with sudden onset of severe eye pain, headache, nausea, blurred vision, and a red, hard eye with elevated intraocular pressure, none of which is seen in this patient. In addition, this condition does not cause improved vision.

E) INCORRECT:

Cataract can cause second sight, in which myopic shift temporarily improves near vision. Cataract typically manifests with progressive, painless blurring of both distance and near vision, glare, and reduced acuity even with correction as the condition progresses. This patient presents with visual acuity with 20/20 distance correction, and slit lamp examination shows no abnormalities. Therefore, cataract is unlikely to be the cause of improved near vision in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with second sight, which is a temporary improvement in near vision.
